title: 10 Philadelphia police recruits resign after trying to cheat on open-book exam
text:
CLOSE Philadelphia has placed 72 of its police officers on administrative duty pending an investigation into alleged bigoted social media posts. Veuer’s Justin Kircher has the story. Buzz60

Ten Philadelphia police recruits resigned after they admitted trying to cheat on an open-book exam, according to local news reports.

A platoon of recruits was set to take a test on vehicle-code law in early June, according to the Philadelphia Inquirer. The day before the test, one of the recruits discovered another trying to give out an answer key, the newspaper reported, citing Philadelphia Police Capt. Sekou Kinebrew.

Jussie Smollett: Chicago police share previously unseen video of rope around actor's neck

The recruit told a supervisor and an investigation was launched, but 10 recruits resigned before it concluded, the newspaper reported. The investigation ultimately found that those 10 recruits had cheated.

The open-book exam meant that recruits were allowed to use approved materials to look up answers during the test, the Inquirer reported.

Arrested for theft: A Florida woman turned in her husband's guns after his domestic violence arrest

“If you didn’t study, it’d just take you longer to find them," Kinebrew told the newspaper.

#EXCLUSIVE: Almost a dozen cadets resign after allegedly planning to cheat on a written exam. One former cadet isn’t excusing his actions but shares how it all went down. pic.twitter.com/vpiSULVXKs — Christie Ileto (@Christie_Ileto) June 25, 2019

Olivier Mardi told KPVI-TV in Philadelphia "the whole class" had the answer key.

"Everybody knows about the answer key," he said to the TV station. "Some recruits had memorized it, instead of writing it down."

Last week, 72 Philadelphia police officers were placed on administrative duty amid an investigation into racist or offensive social-media posts.
